ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Sociological ways of thinking about modern Chinese society and its major trends. Quite fascinating to think about.

I developed a more profound understanding of Chinese culture and society. Specifically, we went over the urban-rural disparity, the aging problem, gender inequality, marriage and dating, and other pertinent topics. As a Chinese American, this was a very enlightening class because it made me feel better equipped to talk about my family's homeland and helped me gain a deeper appreciation for sociology classes.
I learned a lot about contemporary China and many of the social issues there.
really helpful in understanding parts of Chinese culture etc that you do not hear about in the news
learned a lot about China's development since the end of the Cultural Revolution and how those developmental strategies have created the current social climate in China
I developed a greater understanding of social changes occurring within China

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Wished the lectures were less of the professor talking at us. Since it's such a small class, I hoped it would be more seminar-style and engaging. Some of the slides also had way too much text and dense graphs/charts. Also the fact that there were two major final assignments were a lot, considering the lack of guidance we got for both. Wish there was more support on both those fronts.
The professor often posed open-ended questions to the students and encouraged us to answer them while remaining open-minded. It was a very comfortable and safe discussion space. I loved it.
A really great course, very engaging lesson plans, students learn a lot and the class is very dynamic and interactive.
I loved that students lead the class once a week. Really forced us to engage with the material and made workload more manageable.

course material was really interesting but there wasn't much guidance on assignments. In this way, the class could be improved by discussing the assignment expectations more in detail earlier before they are due

The course was a fun exploration of social issues in China. Professor Emma made the class feel like a seminar even though it is a lecture. I thought that the debate at the end of the course could have been more engaging. It might have been because Professor Emma was on maternity leave for the second half of the semester. Also, there could have been more feedback on how the student was doing throughout the course.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes if you'd like to learn more about sociological methods of studying modern Chinese society and its ties in the social, political, economic, and historical background of the nation. Also mused a lot about US-China relationship and comparisons, which I found thought-provoking. Not too much workjust the final assignments that weigh on you.

Yes! Absolutely. Very stress-free with only a debate, final interview project, and final paper to write. There are discussion posts you have to write following each student-led discussion and one that you have to lead as well, but it is very doable. The professor is also very knowledgeable and kind.
Would recommend to any student interested in learning more about China.
Yes, Emma is a great teacher and so kind. I learned a lot
yes, if you are interested in learning more about the cultural differences between China and the US, this is a great class to take
Yes if youre interested in China!
